title: Is That a Mole or Something Else?

content: It may seem like the field of dermatology is all about beauty and aesthetics, but one of my primary roles as a dermatologist in real-life practice is to screen for skin cancer.
What is skin cancer, and who does it affect?
Did you know:
Though the incidence of skin cancer among people with dark skin is lower, it is often diagnosed in its later stages, making treatment more difficult.
What are some common types of skin cancer?
Basal cell carcinoma

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) usually develops on sun-damaged skin and is the most common form of skin cancer, with 2 million Americans diagnosed each year. The average age at diagnosis is 68 years, but it may be found at any age.
The greatest risk factor for developing BCC is sun exposure. Those with lighter skin are at higher risk. BCC is commonly found on your head, neck, hands, forearms, shoulders, and chest.
bullets: Skin cancer is the most common form of cancer in the United States.
1 in 5 Americans will develop skin cancer in their lifetime.
Skin cancer can affect anyone – regardless of your skin color.

content: Luckily, BCC tends to remain local, and the chances of it spreading beyond the skin to lymph nodes and other distant internal organs is extremely low. However, when left untreated, basal cell carcinoma continues to enlarge slowly over time, becoming painful and disfiguring.
Squamous cell carcinoma

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the second most common type of skin cancer worldwide and is generally found when you’re over age 50. The most important factor for developing an SCC is skin type – the lighter your skin, the higher the risk.

Although SCC commonly develops on chronically sun-damaged skin, it may be found anywhere, including the lips, tongue, throat, tonsils, palms of your hands or soles of your feet, and your genitals. There are often other factors at play; cigarette smoking, for example, increases the risk of oral SCC.

Left untreated, SCC can spread to other organs. The risk of it spreading is higher for larger, deeper SCCs (particularly when on the head and neck) and in people with compromised immune systems. SCC is typically curable when diagnosed early.

sections.heading: Melanoma skin cancer
content: Melanoma is an aggressive form of skin cancer originating from pigment-producing cells of the skin (melanocytes). While also treatable when detected early, advanced melanoma can become metastatic. Rates of it spreading to other parts of the body are similar to those of SCC, but your survival is much poorer, with melanoma accounting for 90% of all skin cancer-related deaths. The average age of people diagnosed with melanoma is in their 60s, but melanoma can be seen at any age. There are about 500 children diagnosed with pediatric melanoma annually.

Melanoma may be found in both sun-exposed and sun-protected locations, including your skin, nose, mouth, throat, genitals, nails, palms of your hands, soles of your feet, and eyes. Certain genes can make someone more susceptible to melanoma. Risk factors include a family history of melanoma, a prior personal history of melanoma (if you’ve had one, you’re more likely to develop more), indoor tanning bed use, severe or blistering sunburns at any point in your lifetime (even in childhood), older age, lighter skin, and a large number of moles.

sections.heading: How can I spot skin cancer?
content: BCC can appear as a smooth, shiny, pink bump or a flat, pink, scaly patch on sun-exposed skin. When it comes to SCC, look for pink, red, or skin-colored thickened, firm bumps on sun-damaged skin. They may appear ulcerated, crusty, or scaly. When superficial, they may be flat, pink, scaly patches that resemble BCC.

Most melanomas are brown, tan, or black in color; there may even be multiple colors in the same growth. They may be flat or raised, bleed easily, and have irregular borders. Occasionally, a melanoma may have little to no pigment at all. These are called amelanotic melanomas and are challenging to recognize visually.
Remember the ABCDEs of Melanoma

A : Asymmetry: One half of the lesion does not mirror the other half. B: Border: The borders are irregular or indistinct. C : Color: The color or pigment is not uniform, and there may be varying shades and/or hues. D : Diameter: A pigmented lesion larger than 5 to 6 millimeters in diameter (about the size of a pencil eraser) can be a red flag, although some melanomas can be smaller. E : Evolution: A notable change in a lesion over time raises suspicion for malignancy.

content: Prevention and early detection are key when it comes to skin cancer. Dermatologists are trained to perform thorough physical examinations of the skin to determine which spots are benign versus potentially dangerous. When in doubt, I highly recommend scheduling an evaluation!
For more information, check out the American Academy of Dermatology Skin Cancer Resource Page .
